summary:
Hi! I am a researcher in the Kotlin team at JetBrains and lead a Concurrent Computing lab at JetBrains Research, working on a PhD in the field of concurrency at the same time. My primary research interests are concurrent data structures and algorithms, their verification, and practically applicable code analysis. Here you can find all the recent information about me and my projects.

I am passionate about outdoor activities, such as cycling, skiing, or hiking when not working. Yet, the true love is sailing on small sports boats. 

Please do not hesitate to visit my website for more details, including the list of publications and given talks: https://nikitakoval.org.

projects: [{'title': '1. Synchronization Primitives for Kotlin Coroutines', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'One of the most significant and inspiring projects I have been working on is a new synchronization and communication primitives for Kotlin Coroutines. In short, the project consists of two parts: (1) fast and scalable channels for enabling efficient communication between coroutines and (2) a set of synchronization fair primitives with efficient abortability support. Please check my website by the associated link for more details.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Nikita', 'last_name': 'Koval', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Research Engineer in Computer Science'}]}, {'title': '2. Lincheck: a framework for testing concurrent data structures', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'Lincheck provides a simple and declarative way to write concurrent tests: instead of describing how to perform the test, the user specifies what to test by declaring all the operations to examine, along with the required correctness property. As a result, a typical concurrent test via Lincheck contains only about 15 lines of code and can test all data structures with the same interface, irrelevant of how these data structures are implemented. Given the operations and the contract declaration (linearizability is the default one), Lincheck (1) generates a set of random concurrent scenarios, (2) examines them using either stress-testing or bounded model checking, and (3) verifies that the results of each invocation satisfy the required correctness property, providing an easy-to-follow trace to reproduce the found error in the model checking mode – this significantly simplifies the bug investigation.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Nikita', 'last_name': 'Koval', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Research Engineer in Computer Science'}]}, {'title': '3. Concurrent Graph Algorithms', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'Parallel graph processing is a fundamental and well-studied topic in academia in both theoretical and practical aspects. However, some applications, such as social networks analysis and compilers, require these algorithms to be online, thus, concurrent. This project aims to build practically efficient concurrent algorithms for different aspects of graph processing, including using multi-queues as priority schedulers for some of the algorithms or online dynamic connectivity problems under edge insertion and deletions. Nowadays, most hardware platforms have several NUMA sockets, so it is essential to make all these algorithms NUMA-friendly. Please check my website by the associated link for more details.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Nikita', 'last_name': 'Koval', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Research Engineer in Computer Science'}]}, {'title': '4. Dl-Check: a tool for finding potential deadlocks', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'Dl-Check determines potential deadlock as a lock hierarchy violation and finds them via dynamic analysis in Java programs. This tool is implemented as a Java agent and injects analysis code within class transformation during class loading, making it possible to use Dl-Check without code changes. The base algorithm for finding lock hierarchy violations is based on cycle detection in the lock-order graph’s cycle, leveraging incremental topological order maintenance for that.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Nikita', 'last_name': 'Koval', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Research Engineer in Computer Science'}]}, {'title': '5. Time-test: a library for testing time-based functionality', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'The time-test library helps to test time-dependent functionality via time virtualization. It is implemented as a Java agent and replaces all time-dependent method invocations with its implementations on the fly. Unlike other implementations, it works not only with System.currentTimeMillis() and System.nanoTime() methods, but also with Object.wait(..), Thread.sleep(..), and Unsafe.park(..).', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Nikita', 'last_name': 'Koval', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Research Engineer in Computer Science'}]}]
